sen.j: 天正の陣（てんしょうのじん）は、1585年（天正13年）に全国統一を目指す羽柴秀吉（豊臣秀吉）の命を受けた中国・毛利氏の小早川隆景率いる軍勢が四国は伊予国新居郡（現在の愛媛県新居浜市）に上陸し、金子城城主 金子氏金子元宅率いる地元勢力を圧倒的な戦力で制圧した戦である。
sen.e: The Battle of Tensho (Tensho no Jin) is a battle, in which the army lead by Takakage HAYAKAWA of the Mori clan in Chugoku region landed at Nii Country, Iyo Province (present Niihama City, Ehime Prefecture) in Shikoku in 1585, on receiving the order of Hideyoshi HASHIBA (Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI), who was attempting to integrate whole the nation, and defeated the local troops lead by the lord of Kaneko-jo Castle, Motoie LANEKO of the Kaneko clan with an overwhelming potential.

The Battle of Tensho (Tensho no Jin) was one in which the army led by Takakage HAYAKAWA, of the Mori clan in the Chugoku region, landed at Nii County, Iyo Province (the present-day Niihama City, Ehime Prefecture) in Shikoku in 1585, doing so at the orders of Hideyoshi HASHIBA (Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI), who was attempting to integrate the entire nation, and defeated the local troops led by the lord of Kaneko-jo Castle, Motoie LANEKO, of the Kaneko clan, with overwhelming force.

The Battle of Tensho (Tensho no Jin) was one in which the army led by Takakage KOBAYAKAWA, of the Mori clan in the Chugoku region, landed at Nii County, Iyo Province (the present-day Niihama City, Ehime Prefecture) in Shikoku in 1585, doing so at the orders of Hideyoshi HASHIBA (Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI), who was attempting to integrate the entire nation, and defeated the local troops led by the lord of Kaneko-jo Castle, Motoie KANEKO, of the Kaneko clan, with overwhelming force.

sen.j: 秀吉による四国征伐の中のひとつの戦いである。
sen.e: It is one of the battles in the initiative called Shikoku Conquest projected by Hideyoshi.
It is one of the battles in the initiative called the Shikoku Conquest, which was implemented by Hideyoshi.

sen.j: 1585年7月、毛利輝元は一族の小早川隆景らを四国討伐に向かわせる。
sen.e: July 1585, Terumoto MORI sent Takakage KOBAYAKAWA and others of his family to participate in Shikoku Conquest.

sen.j: 総勢3万余の大軍が瀬戸内海を渡り新居郡内の御代島・沢津（共に現新居浜市）の二手に分かれて上陸し現地の城を破り進軍、新居の総大将 金子元宅率いる金子城を目指す。
sen.e: Big troops with more than 30,000 soldiers in total crossed the Seto Inland Sea and landed from two directions, at Miyoshima and Sawatsu in Nii Country (both of them are situated in present Niihama City), and after having destroyed the castles there, the troops proceeded to Kaneko-jo Castle dominated by Motoie KANRKO, who was the general in commander of Nii Country.

Huge numbers of troops totaling more than 30,000, crossed the Seto Inland Sea and landed from two directions, at Miyoshima and Sawatsu in Nii County (both of them are situated in what is now Niihama City), and, after destroying the castles there, the troops proceeded to Kaneko-jo Castle, which was dominated by Motoie KANRKO, the commander general in Nii County.

sen.j: 金子城には周辺の城から武将が兵を率いて集結していたがその数わずか2千、戦況不利は誰の目にも明らかである。
sen.e: At Kaneko-jo Castle, busho (Japanese military commanders) were gathered from their castles with their own retainers, however, the total number of the soldiers was only 2,000, and the difficult war situation of Kaneko side was visible to all.

sen.e: And there were some busho who surrendered to the enemy.

sen.j: (金子氏は、）かねてより伊予守護の河野氏を通じて毛利氏と友好関係を築こうと働いていたと思われる。

sen.j: 金子氏には、この軍に降伏し毛利の軍門に降る選択肢もあったであろうが、主である土佐国の長宗我部元親に義理立てし徹底抗戦を決意。
sen.e: And the Kaneko clan could have chosen to surrender to the Motoie's army and eventually to the Mori clan, however, it decided do-or-die resistance from a sense of obligation to its feudal lord, Motochika CHOSOKABE, in Tosa Province.

sen.e: Moreover, the Kaneko clan could have chosen to surrender to Motoie's army and eventually to the Mori clan, but instead the decision was made to mount a do-or-die resistance out of a sense of obligation to the clan's feudal lord, Motochika CHOSOKABE, in Tosa Province.

sen.j: 配下の武将もこれに従い金子城の志気は高まった。
sen.e: Busho under the Kaneko clan also followed this decision and the moral of the people at Kaneko-jo Castle was heightened.

sen.j: 元宅は城を弟の金子元春に託して全軍指揮のために守護代 石川氏の高峠城に入り、兵を氷見（現 西条市）の高尾城に集めて軍勢を整えた。
sen.e: Motoie, after having left the castle to the care of his brother, Motoharu KANEKO, entered Takatoki-jo Castle of Shugodai (the acting Military Governor)) Ishikawa clan to command whole the troops, and concentrated the soldiers at Takao-jo Castle in Himi (present Saijo City) to consolidate the force.

sen.j: 金子城では二重三重に毛利軍が取り囲み容赦ない総攻撃が始まった。
sen.e: At Kaneko-jo Castle, the troops of the Mori clan heavily besieged Kaneko-jo Castle and began a merciless full-scale attack.
At Kaneko-jo Castle, the troops of the Mori clan besieged Kaneko-jo Castle and began a merciless, full-scale attack.

sen.j: これに対し死をも覚悟して迎え撃つ金子軍の攻撃も激しかった。
sen.e: The soldiers of the Kaneko clan that were ready for dying attacked back fiercely.
The soldiers of the Kaneko clan, despite being prepared to die, fought back fiercely.

sen.j: また金子氏を慕う領民達も決起し毛利軍にゲリラを仕掛けたと思われる。
sen.e: It seems that also the village people in the territory, who adored their lord, stood up and went guerrilla against the troops of the Mori clan.
It seems that the village people in the territory, who adored their lord, even engaged in guerrilla warfare against the troops of the Mori clan.

sen.j: 主だった神社仏閣も焼き討ちに遭うなどして一帯は壮絶な修羅場と化した。
sen.e: Principal shrines and temples were burned down and the area was transformed into a horrific battlefield.

sen.j: しかし多勢に無勢、やがて金子軍は力尽き金子城は落城した。
sen.e: However, the Kaneko side was outnumbered by the enemy, and the strength of the soldiers finally gave out.
However, the Kaneko side was outnumbered by the enemy, and the soldiers, despite their strength, couldn't outlast the adversary.

sen.j: 金子城を落とした毛利軍は休む間もなく高尾城に向けて進軍。
sen.e: After destroying Kaneko-jo Castle, the troops of the Mori clan continued to proceed to Takao-jo Castle without rest.
After destroying Kaneko-jo Castle, the troops of the Mori clan proceeded toward Takao-jo Castle without rest.

sen.j: 7月12日、要所に陣取った毛利軍は攻撃を開始し城内の兵も果敢に立ち向かった。
sen.e: On July 12, the troops of the Mori clan, which had taken their stand at a strategically critical point, started the attack, and the soldiers in the castle also fought back bravely.

sen.e: On July 12, the troops of the Mori clan, which had taken their stand at a strategically critical point, started the attack, and the soldiers in the castle resisted with great bravery.

sen.j: 双方に多数の戦死者を出し激戦となった。
sen.e: It was a fierce combat and a lot of lives of both sides were lost.

sen.j: 7月17日、もはやこれまでと金子元宅は自ら城に火を放ち、野々市原に討って出た。
sen.e: On July 17, Motoie KANEKO, who was prepared for his death, set fire to his castle and set out to Nonoichihara to attack back.
On July 17, Motoie KANEKO, who was prepared for his death, set fire to his castle and set out toward Nonoichihara for his counter-attack.

sen.e: Both side fought the final battle in disorder, in which Motoie KANEKO and all military commanders (busho) of the Kaneko side, who struggled in vain, were killed, and the battle ended with the victory of the Mori side.

sen.j: 小早川隆景は、勇猛果敢に戦い武士の意気を示し討ち死にした武将達を称えて野々市原に千人塚を建て弔った。
sen.e: Takakage KOBAYAKAWA honored the military commanders (busho), who fought bravely showing the spirit of samurai and died in the battlefield, and gave them a cordial burial by constructing a memorial mound for 1,000 commanders (senninzuka) at Nonoichihara.
